Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Sponge-like crystals with precisely designed nanometer scale pores are critically important for the efficient separation and storage of gases. Technologically, nanoporous semiconductors also show promise as component materials in battery electrodes, chemical sensors, electrocatalysts, and electrochromic materials. Until recently, however, nanoporous crystals have been almost exclusively typecast as electronic insulators. This limitation originates from the trusswork of very strong chemical bonds needed to maintain a stable pore structure. As such, the synthesis of new, electrically conductive, porous crystals stands as an inherently counterintuitive challenge. Efforts toward producing such materials will push the limits of stability and charge delocalization across a crystalline latticework of transition metal nodes and organic linkers.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Metal-organic frameworks are microporous network solids composed of inorganic nodes linked together by organic bridging ligands. While metal-organic frameworks have been extensively developed for their remarkable gas sorption and separation properties, like most porous inorganic materials, they are essentially ionic and electronic insulators. In spite of these properties, this class of materials offers a unique opportunity to explore long-range ion and electron transport in low-dimensional nanoporous systems. The apparent lack of conductive frameworks that have been investigated thus far is not an inherent structural limitation, but rather a result of a lack of focus on electronically interesting structural motifs. That is, the vast majority of frameworks are composed of redox-inactive, closed shell transition metals and organic ligands. In response, metal-organic frameworks engendered with bulk electronic conductivity through the synthesis of open shell and redox-ambiguous scaffolds will be developed. More broadly, the investigation of electronically conductive metal-organic frameworks will explore the limits of long-range electronic communication in low-density hybrid solids and elucidate the primary factors governing the resulting properties. Owing to their crystallinity and the ease of functionalization, metal-organic frameworks can also serve as excellent model systems to better understand and enhance ion transport in nanochannels and nanoporous solids. Thus, the synthesis and characterization of new ion conducting frameworks with a focus on ions that are notoriously difficult to conduct in the solid-state will be pursued.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a promising class of hybrid organic-inorganic solids on the forefront of both chemistry and chemical engineering. These materials have been studied for a variety of industrial applications, particularly chemical separations, gas storage, and catalysis. The properties of these materials, namely their permanent porosity, suggest they could be of use in both lithium-ion and next generation battery technologies, as well as in highly selective chemical sensors, though these applications are largely hindered by the electrically insulating character of most such frameworks. Our research has focused on understanding how charge moves through these frameworks, using this understanding to design highly conductive frameworks, and developing electronic devices based on these conductive frameworks.

Through this research, we have made substantial strides in the fundamental understanding and applications of conductive metal?organic frameworks. Using advanced measurement techniques, such as the study of frameworks squeezed to pressures found at the earth?s core and the utilization of element-specific X-ray-based methods, we have explored the origins of the lower-than-expected conductivities of many frameworks. Further, we have developed frameworks with record one-dimensional and three-dimensional conductivities, as well as frameworks with never-before-seen electronic states, using the principles obtained from the aforementioned techniques. We have developed frameworks which show both interesting electronic and magnetic properties, identifying materials that could revolutionize the fields of data storage and quantum computing. Finally, we have identified conductive frameworks with record energy storage capabilities for lithium-ion batteries, along with frameworks that are capable of serving as cathodes with comparable performance for less expensive battery technologies, particularly Na-ion batteries. We have identified and studied frameworks with predictable conductivity responses to different hydrocarbon gases, which provides insights into the mechanism of sensing in this class of materials. Together, these results have shaped the field of conductive metal?organic frameworks by modifying accepted principles and demonstrating the full capabilities of these materials across a variety of applications.

Beyond the scientific applications of this research, this project has contributed to the education and professional development of seven graduate students, two undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral fellow. These researchers have shared the results of this project at local seminars and national conferences, as well as through peer-reviewed journals, ensuring that these results will have a substantial impact on the field. Furthermore, this award has enabled these researchers to participate in outreach programs in which they visit local elementary schools to provide hands-on science lessons that introduce students to topics in chemistry and careers in science or local middle schools to help students develop independent research projects for science fair competitions.
